courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Elementary Concepts in Risk Management

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 804

courses.description: This is an elementary course that introduces current issues and special topics in risk management. Students are required to present and discuss books and current articles in the related topics assigned by the instructor. Advisory: For majors only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to
(1) learn basic concepts in risk management;
(2) improve their presentation and communication skills; and
(3) improve their spoken and written English.
courses.course_syllabus:
This is an elementary course that introduces current issues and special topics in RMSC.
Students are required to present and discuss books and current articles in the related topics.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):
1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation
2. Email to course instructor
3. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: Textbook: Savage, S. L. (2012). The flaw of averages: why we underestimate risk in the face of uncertainty.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Introduction to Risk Management
courses.description: This course aims at providing a focused introduction to various concepts of risk and risk measures from a scientific perspective. The course will discuss the various roles that risk plays in insurance and financial applications. Current risk measures such as value at risk and shortfall risk will be introduced. These measures will be calculated for recent financial losses to illustrate their usefulness in risk management.
courses.course_syllabus: This course aims at providing a focused introduction to various concepts of risk and risk measures from a scientific perspective. The course will discuss the various roles that risk plays in insurance and financial applications. Current risk measures such as value at risk and shortfall risk will be introduced. These measures will be calculated for recent financial losses to illustrate their usefulness in risk management.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):
1. Mid-term and Term-end course evaluations
courses.required_readings: NA
courses.recommended_readings: 1. Hull (2012). Risk Management and Financial Institutions, 3rd Ed. Wiley.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Introductory Topics in Risk Management
courses.description: This is an intermediate course aiming at introducing current issues and special topics in risk management. Students are required to read books and articles in the related topics assigned by the instructor. Advisory: For majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: RMSC1101 or consent of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
For most classes, students will read a chapter/paper and email the instructor or the TA questions about it. These questions should be the kind of questions you would ask when a visitor presents a seminar or when reviewing a new topic. They should ask the questions as critically and as best as possible.

Most of the classes will consist of a discussion of the papers/chapters, based on a subset of the email questions. One class participant will present a summary of the chapter at the beginning of the discussion. All of the class participants (registered or not) will be expected to participate in the discussion.
courses.course_syllabus:
This is an elementary course aiming at introducing current issues and special
topics in risk management. This course is designed to stimulate analysis of and
provoke discussion about key concepts in risk management. Students will read,
discuss and present chapters of the set text, with a view to considering the ideas of
risk, prediction and statistics raised in that book. The course will also provide
opportunities for students to improve their communication and presentation skills.
Only RMSC majors can register for this course.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):
1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation
2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: [1] Haigh, John (2003). Taking chances: winning with probability. Oxford University Press.
courses.recommended_readings:
[1] Reinhart, C. M., & Rogoff, K. S. (2009). This time is different: Eight centuries of financial folly. Princeton University Press.
[2] Marthinsen, J. E. (2018). Risk takers: uses and abuses of financial derivatives. Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG.
[3] Taleb, N. (2005). Fooled by randomness: The hidden role of chance in life and in the markets. Random House Publishing Group.
[4] Constable, S., & Wright, R. E. (2011). The WSJ Guide to the 50 Economic Indicators That Really Matter: From Big Macs to. Zombie Banks,” the Indicators Smart Investors Watch to Beat the Market,” HarperCollins.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Principles of Credit Risk Management
courses.description: This course introduces the general methodology for credit risk management – how should we handle the possibility our counterparty may not pay us what they owe? Answering this question depends on who the counterparty is and the nature of our contract with them. As such, in this course we explore credit risk models for retail customers, credit risk measures for portfolios, credit mitigation techniques for markets, credit derivatives used by traders and much else besides, all in the context of the latest Basel regulations and the lessons learned from Credit Crisis of 2007-8.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: RMSC2001 or consent of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to

1. understand and expound the Credit Crisis of 2007 and the latest Basel regulations on credit risk.
2. discuss various credit risk mitigation methods
3. describe how to calculate credit risk measures via various methodologies
4. value and utilize credit risk derivatives
5. use statistical software to implement credit risk models
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Retail Credit Risk
3. Credit Risk Mitigation
4. Credit Derivatives
5. The Credit Crisis of 2007-8
6. Credit Risk Measures
7. Credit Risk Regulation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):
1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation
2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: Lecture notes, in the form of PowerPoint presentations, will be uploaded onto the course eLearning platform before lectures. These will contain the examinable material of the course.
courses.recommended_readings:
Hull, J.C. 2018. Risk Management and Financial Institutions, 5th Edition. John Wiley & Sons, New Jersey.
Golin, J. and Delhaise, P. 2013. The Bank Credit Analysis Handbook, 2nd Edition. John Wiley & Sons, New Jersey.
Crouhy, M., Galai, D. and Mark, R. 2014. The Essential of Risk Management, 2nd Edition. McGraw-Hill, New York.
Gregory, J. 2020. The xVA Challenge: Counterparty Credit Risk, Funding, Collateral, and Capital, 4th Edition. John Wiley & Sons, UK

courses.title: Special Topics in Risk Management
courses.description: This is an advanced course aiming at introducing current issues and special topics in risk management. Students are required to present books and current articles in the related topics assigned by the instructor. Advisory: For majors only.

Students are required to present books and current articles in the related topics assigned by the instructor.

courses.required_readings: Chan, Ernie. (2013) Algorithmic trading: winning strategies and their rationale. Wiley.
courses.recommended_readings: Prado, Marcos Lopez de. (2018) Advances in Financial Machine Learning. Wiley.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Simulation Methods for Risk Management Science and Finance
courses.description: This course starts with presenting standard topics in simulation including random variable generations, variance reduction methods and statistical analysis of simulation outputs. The course then reviews the applications of these methods to derivative security pricing. Topics addressed include: importance sampling, martingale control variables, stratification and the estimation of derivatives. Additional topics include the use of low discrepancy sequence (quasi-random numbers), pricing American options and scenario simulation for risk management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite:RMSC2001 or consent of instructor
courses.course_syllabus: This course starts with presenting standard topics in simulation including random variable generations, variance reduction methods and statistical analysis of simulation outputs. The course then reviews the applications of these methods to derivative security pricing. Topics addressed include: importance sampling, martingale control variables, stratification and the estimation of derivatives. Additional topics include the use of low discrepancy sequence (quasi-random numbers), pricing American options and scenario simulation for risk management.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):

1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation

2. Email to course instructor

3. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: Chan, N.H. and Wong, H.Y. (2006), Simulation Techniques in Financial Risk Management, Wiley.
courses.recommended_readings:
Hull, J, Options, Futures and Other Derivatives, Prentice Hall (the most updated edition).

Ross, S.M. (2002), Simulation 3rd Edition, Academic Press.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Financial Data Analytics with Machine Learning

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401

courses.description: This course covers modern data analysis techniques that are commonly used in finance and risk management. Topics include applications of multivariate techniques for data cleansing and modeling such as principal component analysis and canonical correlation analysis to asset management, Extreme Value theory, Value-at-Risks, GARCH modeling in estimating volatility, time series methods in term-structure analysis. Besides, the next few introductory topics in machine learning will also be covered, such as recommender system, logistic regression, k-means clustering, perceptrons, decision trees, artificial neural network, stochastic gradient descent, Naive Bayes Classifiers and Bayesian networks.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite:RMSC2001, STAT2001 and STAT2006, or consent of instructor
courses.course_syllabus:
Business, Finance and Risk Management Science. Statistical packages such as R, SAS
and EXCEL will be used to demonstrate these methods. Topics are as follows:
• Simulating Multivariate Normal Random Numbers
• Estimating Volatilities and Correlations
• Risk Measure and Extreme Value Theory
• Principal Component Analysis, Recommender Systems
• Binary Logistic Regression, Multinomial Logit, Perceptrons
• Decision Tree
• k-means Clustering
• Artificial Neural Network, Stochastic Gradient Descent
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):
1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation
2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: NA
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Hull, J., Risk Management and Financial Institutions, Prentice Hall
2. Johnson, R.A. and Wichern, D.W. Applied Multivariate statistical analysis, 6th edition, Prentice Hall
3. David Ruppert and David S. Matteson, Statistics and Data Analysis for Financial Engineering: with R examples, 2nd ed. 2015 edition, Springer
4. Kevin P. Murphy and Francis Bach, Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective (Adaptive Computation and Machine Learning), 1st edition, The MIT Press
5. (日)中井悅司, 機器學習入門之道, 人民郵電

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Statistical Modelling in Financial Markets
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce the current developments in risk management in the financial markets. Risk management ideas associated with three general important areas in finance will be discussed: asset management, derivative pricing and fixed income models. Emphasis will be placed on the statistical modelling aspects on some of the commonly used models in these areas.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite:RMSC2001 or consent of instructor
courses.course_syllabus: This course is designed to introduce the current developments of risk management in the financial markets. Two general important areas of risk management in finance: (1) asset management and (2) derivative pricing. Emphasis will be placed on the statistical modeling aspects on some of the commonly used models in the area of market risk.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):

1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation

2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: David G. Luenberger, Investment Science, 7th edition, Oxford University Press
courses.recommended_readings: David Ruppert, Statistics and Finance – An Introduction, Springer-Verlag

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Theory of Risk and Insurance
courses.description: This course covers the theory of risk and its applications to insurance. Topics include: classical and stochastic risk models, ruin theory, claims modelling and evaluations, risk premium pricing, loss distributions and creditability theory.
courses.course_syllabus: Risk can be thought as the potential losses in accidents. The amount of loss in each accident and the frequency of the occurrence of accidents should be considered to quantify risk. To eliminate these potential losses, individual will seek for insurance. From an individual point of view, insurance is an economic device whereby the individual substitutes a small certain cost (the premium) for a large uncertain financial loss (the contingency insured against) that would exist if there were not for insurance. In this course, the modeling of frequency and severity will be studied. The aggregate loss model will then be introduced. Then credibility theory will be discussed.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):

1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation

2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: Klugman, S.A., Panjer, H.H. and Willmot, G.E. Loss Models: From Data to Decisions. 2nd Edition. John Wiley, 2004.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Stochastic Calculus for Finance and Risk
courses.description: This course starts with the introduction of the concepts of arbitrage and risk-neutral pricing. It then proceeds to discuss the stochastic calculus foundations for continuous-time finance models. Topics include: Brownian motion, stochastic integral, Itô's formula, Girsanov's change of measure, and the relationship between stochastic calculus and partial differential equations. Examples will be taken from equity options, including the Black-Scholes formula for foreign exchange and term-structure models.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite:RMSC2001 or consent of instructor
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to
(1) do the basic option pricing (the Black-Sholes approach) for European and American options under the assumption that the stock price behaves as a drifted Brownian Motion; and
(2) do the basic manipulation of stochastic integrations and stochastic partial differential equations.
courses.course_syllabus:
Stochastic Calculus is an advance tool for modeling prices of risky assets. In this course you will learn the basics of stochastic calculus without going through the rigorous mathematics of measure theory. The following topics will be covered in this course:

1. Examples of arbitrage and pricing in a single period forward option
2. The multi-period binary model
3. Conditional expectation and Martingale
4. Continuous stochastic process and Brownian motion
5. Stochastic integral and Ito’s formula
6. Stochastic differential equation
7. Applications of stochastic calculus in finance
8. The Black-Scholes Model and pricing for European option
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):
1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation
2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: NA
courses.recommended_readings:
A course in Financial Calculus / A. Etherridge
Introduction to Stochastic Calculus with Application / F. C. Klebaner

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Operational Risk Management
courses.description: This course introduces the general methodology for operational risk management. Special emphasis will be placed on the analytical and modeling techniques for operational risk. Contents include Basel regulations, loss models, extreme value theory, copula, operational value-at-risk and operational risk derivatives. Machine learning techniques for managing operational risk will also be explored. The use of statistical packages R will be demonstrated.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: RMSC2001 or consent of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to
1. understand the Basel regulations on operational risk.
2. build statistical models for operational risk
3. understand extreme value theory and copula models
4. calculate operational value-at-risk and price operational risk derivatives
5. use statistical software to conduct machine learning algorithms and statistical inference and for operation risk models
courses.course_syllabus: Operational risk refers to the uncertainties and hazards a company faces under its day-to-day business activities. It usually involves some events that rarely happen but lead to huge lost. Therefore, extreme value theory is crucial to characterize the behaviors of these events. Moreover, copula is an important tool to model the dependency among the operational risks from several business lines. In this course we investigate the use of extreme value theory and copula on managing operational risk. Machine learning techniques for managing operational risk will also be explored.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):
1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation
2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: NA
courses.recommended_readings:
Cruz, M. 2002. Modeling, Measuring and Hedging Operational Risk. John Wiley & Sons, London.
Panjer, H.H. 2006. Operational Risk – Modeling Analytics. John Wiley & Sons, New Jersey.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Risk Management with Derivatives Concepts
courses.description: This course aims at understanding the application of derivatives theories for the practical risk management. It starts by reviewing basic concepts of pricing and hedging derivatives, like risk-neutral valuation, arbitrage strategies, hedging strategies, implied volatilities and the Greeks. The Value-at-Risk framework for derivatives positions is discussed. Student will also learn how to apply option theoretic approach to credit risk management. Specifically, the capital structure model will be applied to measure the default probability. The Moody's KMV methodology and CreditRisk+ are introduced. Advisory: For Risk Management Science, Quantitative Finance and Risk Management Science, Statistics majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: RMSC2001, 4001 & 4003 or consent of instructor.
courses.course_syllabus: This course aims at understanding the application of derivatives theories for the practical risk management. It starts by reviewing basic concepts of pricing and hedging derivatives, like risk-neutral valuation, arbitrage strategies, hedging strategies, implied volatilities and the Greeks. The Value-at-Risk framework for derivatives positions is discussed. Student will also learn how to apply option theoretic approach to credit risk management. Specifically, the capital structure model will be applied to measure the default probability. The Moody's KMV methodology and CreditRisk+ are introduced.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Comments and feedback can be made via the following channel(s):

1. Mid-term and term-end course evaluation

2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: J. Hull. Options, Futures and Other Derivatives (The 6th edition or after)
courses.recommended_readings: N.H. Chan and H.Y. Wong (2006). Simulation Techniques in Financial Risk Management, Wiley

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Research Project
courses.description: This course provides students with the opportunity to apply their knowledge to solve real-world problems. Students are required to complete a group project, give a final project presentation and submit a written report, on which their assessment is based. Advisory: For majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: RMSC3101 or consent of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon course completion, students should be able to
(1) conduct research on practical financial and risk management problems;
(2) apply the statistical methods learnt in different courses; and
(3) learn presentation skills.
courses.course_syllabus: The course is to provide an opportunity for students to apply their knowledge to solve real-world problem. Students will be required to complete an individual project, give a final project presentation, and submit a written report, on which their assessment will be based.
courses.feedback_evaluation: There is no formal lectures for the course. Students meet up with the course instructor individually to discuss the corresponding projects.
courses.required_readings: No Required and Recommended Readings. Students read different academic papers according to the topics of their research projects.
courses.recommended_readings: No Required and Recommended Readings.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Research Project in Risk Analytics
courses.description: In this course, students are required to review selected readings in academic journal in Statistics and Risk Management. Students are required to form a group to complete a project, in which the latest techniques of Risk Analytics are applied to tackle a real-world problem. They are also required to submit an interim and final written report, on which their assessment will be based. Advisory: For majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: RMSC3101 or consent of instructor.
courses.course_syllabus: In this course, students are required to review selected readings in academic journal in Statistics and Risk Management. Students are required to form a group to complete a project, in which the latest techniques of Risk Analytics are applied to tackle a real-world problem. They are also required to submit an interim and final written report, on which their assessment will be based. Advisory: For majors only.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students can provide feedback via the following channels:
1. Term-end course and teaching evaluation (mandatory).
2. Student-staff consultative committee meeting(s).
courses.required_readings: No Required and Recommended Readings.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Practicum
courses.description: The course serves to provide a bridge between the classroom and the real business world. Students will be required to complete a group project assigned by a company or an organization on a part-time basis. A team of three to five students will undertake a project under the joint supervision of an instructor and a member of the company or organization. Students will be required to give a final project presentation and submit a written report, on which their assessment will be based. Advisory: For majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: RMSC2001 & FINA2010 or 2110 or consent of instructor.
courses.course_attributes:
Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship

They are also required to submit an interim and final written report, on which their assessment will be based. Advisory: For majors only.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Advanced Statistical Theory in Risk Management
courses.description: This course discusses modern applications of advanced statistical methods in finance. Methods include Monte Carlo simulation, EWMA and GARCH model for estimating volatilities and correlations, calculation of Value at Risk using different approaches, data mining methods including Principal component analysis, Logistic regression, Multinomial logit, Linear Discriminant analysis, Classification Tree and Artificial Neural Network.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science and MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics
courses.course_syllabus:
* Simulating multivariate normal random numbers
* Estimating volatilities and correlations
* Value at Risk
* Principal component analysis
* Binary Logistic regression and Multinomial logit
* Linear Discriminant analysis
* Classification Tree
* Artificial Neural Network
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Term-end course and teaching evaluation

2. Staff-student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: Lecture notes
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Hull, J., Options, Futures, and other derivatives. Pearson.

2. Johnson, R.A. and Wichern, D.W. Applied Multivariate statistical analysis, Prentice Hall.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Principles of Risk Management
courses.description: This course provides students with fundamental concepts of risk and risk management. It further introduces risk management tools used in financial products. Topics include market risk, credit risk and integrated risk management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science and MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Risk Management

2. Probability and Statistics for Risk Management

3. Forward and Futures

4. Options

5. Binomial Tree Model

6. Black-Scholes Model

7. Value at Risk

8. Credit Risk Modelling
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Term-end course and teaching evaluation
2. Staff-student Consultative Meeting

2. Hull, J (2014). Option, Futures and Other Derivatives 9th edition, Pearson, Boston

3. Jorion, P. (2007). Value at Risk 3rd edition, McGraw-Hill, New York

4. Hull, J. (2018). Risk Management and Financial Institutions, 5th Edition, John Wiley & Sons.

5. Van Horne (2002), Financial Management and Policies, 12th edition, Prentice Hall

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Risk Measures
courses.description: Risk measurement and quantification are the fundamentals of risk management procedures. This course discusses various types of risk measures but mainly focuses on the methodologies of calculating Value-at-Risk (VaR) such as historical simulation, parametric VaR, delta-gamma approximation and Monte-Carlo simulation. The uses of VaR in risk management are also addressed. Topics include portfolio risk management, asset allocation and measuring the performance of portfolio managers.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science, MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics and MPhil Risk Management Science
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Regulatory Capital Standards with VaR

2. Measuring Financial Risk

3. Computing Value at Risk

4. Back-Testing VaR Models

5. Portfolio Risk: Analytical Methods

6. Forecasting Risks and Correlations

7. VaR Methods and RiskMetrics

8. Stress Testing

9. Credit Risk

10. Liquidity Risk

11. Using VaR for Active Risk Management and Investment

12. Coherent Risk Measures

13. Integrated Risk Management
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Term-end course and teaching evaluation

2. Staff-student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: Lecture notes will be available online.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Jorion, P. 2006. Value at Risk (3rd Edition), McGraw-Hill.

2. N.H. Chan and H.Y. Wong 2015. Simulation Techniques in Financial Risk Management (2nd Edition), John Wiley & Sons.

3. Hull, J. 2018. Risk Management and Financial Institutions. (5th Edition). John Wiley & Sons.

4. Hull, J. 2014. Option, Futures and Other Derivatives. (9th Edition). Pearson

5. Hogg, R. and Tanis. E., et al. 2014. Probability and Statistical Inference. (9th Edition). Macmillan.

Topics addressed include importance sampling, martingale control variables, stratification and the estimation of derivatives. Additional topics include the use of low discrepancy sequence (quasi-random numbers), pricing American options and scenario simulation for risk management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science and MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics
courses.course_syllabus: This course starts with presenting standard topics in simulation including random variable generations, variance reduction methods and statistical analysis of simulation outputs. The course then reviews the applications of these methods to derivative security pricing. Topics addressed include importance sampling, martingale control variables, stratification and the estimation of derivatives. Additional topics include the use of low discrepancy sequence (quasi-random numbers), pricing American options and scenario simulation for risk management.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Term-end course and teaching evaluation

2. Staff-student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: Chan, N.H. and Wong, H.Y. (2006), Simulation Techniques in Financial Risk Management, Wiley.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Amussen, S. and Glynn, P.W. (2007). Stochastic Simulation: Algorithms and Analysis. Springer, New York.
2. McLeish, D.L. (2005). Monte Carlo: Simulation and Finance. Wiley, New York.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Interest Rates and Fixed Incomes Risk Management
courses.description: Fixed income securities are highly sensitive to the fluctuation of interest rates. Thus interest rate modelling becomes crucial for pricing and managing fixed income securities. This course introduces various types of fixed income securities and interest rate models. It covers the celebrated Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM) model as well as some term-structure models including Ho-Lee, Hull-White and the CIR models.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science, MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics and MSc in Data Science and Business Statistics
courses.course_syllabus: Fixed income securities are highly sensitive to the fluctuation of interest rates. Thus interest rate modelling becomes crucial for pricing and managing fixed income securities. This course introduces various types of fixed income securities and interest rate models. It covers the celebrated Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM) model as well as some term-structure models including Ho-Lee, Hull-White and the CIR models.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Term-end course and teaching evaluation

2. Staff-student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: L. Martellini, P. Priaulet and S. Priaulet, Fixed-income Securities: Valuation, Risk Management and Portfolio Strategies, Wiley
courses.recommended_readings: Hull, Options, Futures and Other Derivatives.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Credit Risk Management
courses.description: The Credit Crisis of 2007 devastated the global financial industry and demonstrated that, despite unprecedented financial sophistication, proper credit risk management is vital for the good health of any financial institution. In this course, we will cover the cat-and-mouse history of regulation of credit, taking us to the present day. Along the way, we cover various attempts at modeling and quantifying credit risk, which will lead us through topics like VaR, copulas, credit derivatives, different credit risk methodologies (e.g. Credit Risk Plus, CreditMetrics) and much else besides. We will also discuss various case histories of financial institutions failing due to poor credit risk management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science and MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics
courses.course_syllabus: The Credit Crisis of 2007 devastated the global financial industry and demonstrated that, despite unprecedented financial sophistication, proper credit risk management is vital for the good health of any financial institution. In this course, we will cover the cat-and-mouse history of regulation of credit, taking us to the present day. Along the way, we cover various attempts at modeling and quantifying credit risk, which will lead us through topics like VaR, copulas, credit derivatives, different credit risk methodologies (e.g. Credit Risk Plus, CreditMetrics) and much else besides. We will also discuss various case histories of financial institutions failing due to poor credit risk management.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term evaluation

2. Term-end course and teaching evaluation

3. Staff-student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: Teaching materials to be provided by the course lecturer(s).
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Hull, J. 2018. Risk Management and Financial Institutions. 5th ed. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons.

2. Meissner, G. (2014). Correlation Risk Modeling and Management: An Applied Guide including the Basel III Correlation Framework. John Wiley & Sons.

3. Chacko, G. et al. (2016). Credit Derivatives: A Primer On Credit Risk, Modeling and Instruments. Pearson.

4. The Hong Kong Institute of Bankers. 2012. Credit Risk Management. John Wiley & Sons, Singapore.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Risk Management in Financial Institutions

meetings.instructor:
Dr Joaquin Jose CALVO TORRES, 
Mr. Israel VALCARCEL ALVAREZ

courses.description: The course aims to discuss how risk management is applied in the banking sector.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Data Science and Business Statistics, MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics, MSc in Advanced Studies in Statistics and Data Science and MPhil Risk Management Science
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to,

1. Understand the main risks associated with the banking business and the tools to manage them.
2. Assess the financial risk profile of a corporate or a bank.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Foundations of risk management
2. Risk management function in financial institutions
3. Fundamentals of credit risk
4. Credit analysis and reporting
5. Financial markets and products
6. Market risk and counterparty credit risk
7. Regulatory capital in banking
8. Risk management in project finance
9. Other financial risks
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Term-end course and teaching evaluation

2. Staff-student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: Lecture notes will be provided.
courses.recommended_readings: Lecture notes will be provided.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Portfolio Theory with Risk Management Perspective
courses.description: The course introduces the general theory of financial portfolio based on utility theory. Non-arbitrage pricing theory based on the idea of risk management will be applied. Selected topics include utility functions, risk aversion, the St Petersburg paradox, dynamic asset pricing, forecast and valuation, portfolio optimisation under budget constraints, wealth consumption, and growth versus income.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science, MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics and MPhil Risk Management Science
courses.course_syllabus: The course introduces the general theory of financial portfolio based on utility theory. Non-arbitrage pricing theory based on the idea of risk management will be applied. Selected topics include utility functions, risk aversion, the St Petersburg paradox, dynamic asset pricing, forecast and valuation, portfolio optimisation under budget constraints, wealth consumption, and growth versus income.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Term-end course and teaching evaluation

2. Staff-student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: Teaching materials to be provided by the course lecturer(s).
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Campbell, J. Y., Lo, A. W. and MacKinlay, C. (1996). *The Econometrics of Financial Markets*: Princeton University Press.

2. Ingersoll, J. E. (1987). *Theory of Financial Decision Making*: Rowman & Littleeld.

3. Tsay, R. S. (2010). *Analysis of Financial Time Series, 3rd Edition*: Wiley & Sons.

4. Tsay, R. S. (2013). *Multivariate Time Series Analysis: With R and Financial Applications*: Wiley & Sons.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Risk and Financial Data Analytics with Python
courses.description: The aim of the course is to provide students with a broad understanding of the principles and techniques of Python coding for finance applications on Jupyter notebook and/or other programming interfaces. Following an introduction to the basics of Python, the course is further divided into two main sections. The first part covers the fundamentals of data reduction and modelling applied specifically to financial data with Python libraries. Techniques for derivative pricing, risk measures estimation with Python are also discussed. The second part emphasises on several specific examples of applying state-of-the-art machine learning tools for various modelling/ analyses. Understanding the problems covered in the course will be important to students pursing a career in a rapidly expanding technology-intensive field of finance and risk management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science and Data Analytics; MSc in Data Science and Business Statistics
courses.course_syllabus: The aim of the course is to provide students with a broad understanding of the principles and techniques of Python coding for finance applications on Jupyter notebook and/or other programming interfaces. Following an introduction to the basics of Python, the course is further divided into two main sections. The first part covers the fundamentals of data reduction and modelling applied specifically to financial data with Python libraries. Techniques for derivative pricing, risk measures estimation with Python are also discussed. The second part emphasises on several specific examples of applying state-of-the-art machine learning tools for various modelling/ analyses. Understanding the problems covered in the course will be important to students pursing a career in a rapidly expanding technology-intensive field of finance and risk management.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Mid-term course evaluation
2. Term-end course and teaching evaluation
2. Staff-student Consultative Meeting
courses.required_readings: Please refer to recommended readings.
courses.recommended_readings:
i. Hilpisch, Y. (2014). *Python for Finance: Mastering Data-Driven Finance 2nd Edition*: O’Reilly.
ii. Hilpisch, Y. (2015). *Derivatives Analytics with Python: Data Analysis, Models, Simulation, Calibration
and Hedging*: Wiley.
iii. \*Lewinson, E. (2020). *Python for Finance Cookbook: Over 50 recipes for applying modern Python
libraries to financial data analysis*: Packt.
iv. Lutz, M. (2013). *Learning Python, 5th Edition*: O’Reilly.
v. \*Matthes, E. (2019). *Python Crash Course, 2nd Edition: A Hands-On, Project-Based Introduction To
Programming*: No Starch Press.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Practicum
courses.description: The course serves to provide a bridge between the classroom and the real business world. Students will be required to complete a project assigned by a company or an organization on a part-time basis. Each student will undertake a project under the joint supervision of an instructor and a member of the company or organization. Students will be required to give a final project presentation and submit a written report on which their assessment will be based.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Risk Management Science and MSc in Risk Management Science and Data Analytics
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to course ontline.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Please refer to course ontline.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to course ontline.

courses.subject: RMSC
courses.title: Research for Thesis
courses.description: Students are required to conduct research under the supervision of their advisors.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil Risk Management Science
courses.course_syllabus: This course requires students to meet their supervisors regularly to discuss research problems, and/or other relevant topics that can contribute to the students theses.
courses.feedback_evaluation: The supervisor should evaluate the grade (pass/fail) of individual advisee based on the progress in conducting research for his/her thesis.
courses.required_readings: N/A
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to course outline
